questions.question: A manufacturer ships goods to a retailer on consignment. The manufacturer recognizes revenue when:

options.A: Goods are shipped to the retailer
options.B: The retailer sells the goods to end customers

questions.explanation: In consignment arrangements, the consignor retains control until the consignee sells to end customers. Revenue is recognized when the consignee makes the sale, not when goods are transferred to the consignee.
questions.tip: Consignment: Consignor keeps control and ownership. Revenue when consignee sells to final customer.

questions.conceptTested: Adjusting for time value of money
questions.question: A contract requires payment 3 years after delivery. The transaction price should be adjusted for:

options.B: The time value of money (significant financing component)

questions.explanation: When payment timing provides significant financing benefit, adjust the transaction price. Record revenue at the present value of future payment and recognize interest income over the payment period.
questions.tip: Significant financing: >1 year timing difference typically significant. PV revenue + interest over time.

questions.question: Under FIFO, ending inventory using perpetual method compared to periodic method is:

options.B: Always lower
options.D: Higher or lower depending on price trends

questions.explanation: FIFO produces the same ending inventory and COGS whether using perpetual or periodic systems. The oldest costs go to COGS regardless of when sales occur. This is unique to FIFO; LIFO and average differ between systems.
questions.tip: FIFO: Same result perpetual vs periodic. LIFO and weighted average: Different results between systems.

questions.question: At year-end, significant unfavorable production variances should be:

options.A: Expensed entirely to cost of goods sold
options.B: Allocated to inventory and cost of goods sold
options.D: Charged to a prior period adjustment

questions.explanation: Significant variances should be allocated between ending inventory and COGS to approximate actual cost. Immaterial variances may be expensed to COGS. Standard costs must approximate actual for GAAP.
questions.tip: Variances: Material = allocate to inventory and COGS. Immaterial = expense to COGS. Goal: approximate actual.

questions.question: Long-lived assets are grouped for impairment testing at:

options.B: The entity level
options.C: The lowest level of identifiable cash flows

questions.explanation: Assets are grouped at the lowest level for which identifiable cash flows are largely independent. This asset group is the unit of account for impairment testing of long-lived assets (different from goodwill's reporting unit).
questions.tip: Long-lived impairment: Asset group level (lowest independent cash flows). Goodwill: Reporting unit level.

questions.question: A company receives land as a donation from a local government to build a factory. The land should be recorded at:

options.A: Zero, since no cost was incurred
options.B: Fair value, with a credit to contribution revenue or deferred revenue

questions.explanation: Donated assets are recorded at fair value. The credit depends on whether conditions exist: unconditional = revenue immediately; conditional = deferred revenue until conditions met.
questions.tip: Donated assets: FV. Credit to revenue (or deferred if conditional). No conditions = immediate revenue.

questions.question: Initial franchise fees are recognized as revenue by the franchisor when:

options.B: Cash is received
options.C: The franchisor has substantially performed its obligations

questions.explanation: Under ASC 606, initial franchise fees are recognized when the franchisor satisfies its performance obligations. If the fee covers distinct services (training, setup), recognize over time as services are provided.
questions.tip: Franchise fees: Recognize as performance obligations satisfied. Often over time during setup period.

questions.question: Customer relationships acquired in a business combination are:

options.A: Included in goodwill because they're not separable
options.B: Recognized as a separate intangible asset if identifiable

questions.explanation: Customer relationships are identifiable intangibles if: (1) separable (can be sold, licensed, etc.), OR (2) arise from contractual/legal rights. Non-contractual relationships can be separable and thus recognized separately from goodwill.
questions.tip: Customer intangibles: Separable OR contractual = recognize separately. Amortize over expected relationship life.

questions.question: When debt securities are transferred from available-for-sale to held-to-maturity, the unrealized gain in AOCI is:

options.B: Amortized over the remaining life as a yield adjustment

questions.explanation: AFS to HTM transfer: The unrealized gain/loss in AOCI at transfer date is amortized to interest income over the remaining life of the security (as a yield adjustment), similar to premium/discount amortization.
questions.tip: AFS→HTM: AOCI balance amortized over remaining life. HTM→AFS: Unrealized amount goes to AOCI immediately.

questions.question: Equity securities without readily determinable fair values may be measured at:

options.B: Cost minus impairment, plus or minus observable price changes

questions.explanation: The measurement alternative for equity securities without readily determinable FV: Cost, minus impairment, plus/minus changes from observable transactions in identical or similar securities of the same issuer.
questions.tip: No FV available: Measurement alternative = cost ± observable changes − impairment. Qualitative impairment assessment.

questions.question: A lessee provides a residual value guarantee to the lessor. In the lease liability calculation, the lessee includes:

options.B: The amount probable of being owed under the guarantee
options.C: Nothing until the guarantee is called

questions.explanation: Lessees include in the lease liability only the amount expected to be owed under residual value guarantees—the amount by which expected residual value is less than the guaranteed amount.
questions.tip: Lessee RVG: Include expected payment only (shortfall). Lessor: Include full guarantee in lease receivable.

questions.question: Under ASC 842, new leveraged leases are:

options.A: Accounted for using special leveraged lease accounting
options.B: No longer permitted; use standard lessor accounting

questions.explanation: ASC 842 eliminated leveraged lease accounting for new leases. Existing leveraged leases were grandfathered under ASC 840 rules. New leveraged arrangements use standard sales-type, direct financing, or operating lease accounting.
questions.tip: Leveraged leases: Grandfathered only for existing. New leases = standard lessor accounting.

questions.question: A company sells 1,000 units with a 2-year warranty. Experience shows 3% will need repair at $100 each. The warranty liability at sale is:
questions.explanation: Warranty liability = Expected claims = 1,000 units × 3% × $100 = $3,000. Record warranty expense and liability when products are sold, not when claims are made.
questions.tip: Warranty accrual: Estimate at sale. Units × Defect rate × Cost per repair. Adjust estimates as needed.

questions.question: Gift cards not expected to be redeemed (breakage) should be recognized as revenue:

options.B: When the cards expire
options.C: In proportion to redemptions if pattern is estimable, or when likelihood of redemption is remote
options.D: Never; amounts are escheated to the state

questions.explanation: Under ASC 606, breakage is recognized proportionately as other redemptions occur (if entity expects to be entitled to breakage). If breakage can't be estimated, recognize when redemption becomes remote.
questions.tip: Breakage: Recognize proportionately with redemptions if estimable. Otherwise, wait until redemption remote.

questions.question: A company reduces the par value of its common stock from $10 to $1 per share. This change results in:

options.A: A gain in the income statement
options.B: A transfer from common stock to additional paid-in capital
options.C: A reduction in total stockholders' equity

questions.explanation: Reducing par value decreases the common stock account and increases APIC by the same amount. Total equity is unchanged. It's a reclassification within equity, not a transaction affecting earnings.
questions.tip: Par value reduction: Dr. Common Stock, Cr. APIC. Total equity unchanged. Just a reclassification.

questions.question: When convertible preferred stock is converted to common stock, the entry credits common stock and APIC based on:

options.A: Fair value of common stock issued
options.B: Carrying value of the preferred stock
options.C: Original issue price of the preferred
options.D: Par value of preferred times conversion ratio

questions.explanation: At conversion, debit preferred stock for its carrying value (par + any related APIC). Credit common stock at par and APIC for the remainder. No gain or loss is recognized on conversion.
questions.tip: Preferred conversion: Book value method. Transfer carrying value to common. No gain/loss recognized.

questions.question: A company uses straight-line depreciation for books and accelerated for tax. In early years, this creates:

options.B: A deferred tax liability

questions.explanation: Accelerated tax depreciation creates higher tax deductions early, lower taxable income now, but future taxable amounts when the pattern reverses. This temporary difference creates a deferred tax liability.
questions.tip: Accelerated tax depreciation → DTL (paid less tax now, will pay more later). Pattern reverses over asset life.

questions.question: A deferred tax liability for unremitted earnings of a foreign subsidiary is not recognized if:

options.B: The earnings are indefinitely reinvested outside the US
options.D: The foreign tax rate is higher

questions.explanation: Under the indefinite reversal criterion, no DTL is recorded for unremitted foreign earnings if the earnings are expected to be indefinitely reinvested abroad. Management must assert and demonstrate this intent.
questions.tip: Indefinite reinvestment: No DTL on foreign earnings. Management must assert permanent reinvestment intent.

questions.question: A special revenue fund is used to account for:

options.B: Resources legally restricted for specific purposes other than debt service or capital projects

questions.explanation: Special revenue funds account for resources restricted by law, grant, or donor for specific purposes (other than debt service, capital projects, or permanent funds). Examples: gas tax for roads, grants for specific programs.
questions.tip: Special revenue: Restricted resources for specific purposes. Not debt service (that's debt service fund).

questions.question: A government issues bonds to construct a new building. The bond proceeds are recorded in:

options.B: Capital projects fund as other financing sources

questions.explanation: Bond proceeds for capital projects are recorded in a capital projects fund as 'other financing sources—bond proceeds.' The capital project expenditures are also recorded in this fund. The building is capitalized in government-wide statements.
questions.tip: Capital projects fund: Bond proceeds (OFS) and construction expenditures. Asset appears in government-wide only.

questions.question: An NFP holds a fundraising dinner where attendees pay $200 for a meal worth $50. The NFP should recognize:

options.B: $50 as exchange revenue and $150 as contribution revenue
options.D: $50 as contribution revenue and $150 as exchange revenue

questions.explanation: Special events have both exchange and contribution elements. The fair value of benefits provided ($50) is exchange revenue; the excess paid ($150) is contribution revenue. Both reported gross typically.
questions.tip: Special events: Split between exchange (FV of benefits) and contribution (excess). Report both components.

questions.question: A charitable remainder trust where the NFP is the remainder beneficiary is initially recorded at:

options.B: Present value of the expected remainder interest
options.C: Full fair value of trust assets

questions.explanation: The NFP records an asset and contribution revenue for the present value of the expected remainder interest. The remainder interest increases over time (accretion) as the lead interest is paid out.
questions.tip: Split-interest: Record PV of remainder. Accrete over time. Revalue for actuarial changes.

questions.question: When a subsidiary is acquired on July 1, the consolidated income statement includes the subsidiary's operations for:

options.B: Only July 1 through year-end

questions.explanation: Consolidated financial statements include subsidiary results only from the acquisition date forward. Pre-acquisition subsidiary income belongs to previous owners and is not included in consolidated income.
questions.tip: Midyear acquisition: Include sub's results from acquisition date only. Pro forma disclosure may show full year.

questions.question: When a subsidiary incurs a loss, the non-controlling interest's share of the loss:

options.A: Is limited to the NCI balance (can't go negative)
options.B: Is allocated even if it creates a negative NCI balance
options.C: Is absorbed entirely by the parent
options.D: Is deferred until profits are available

questions.explanation: Under current GAAP, losses are allocated to NCI based on ownership percentage, even if this results in a negative (debit) NCI balance. The old rule limiting loss allocation to NCI balance was eliminated.
questions.tip: NCI loss allocation: Full share of loss allocated even if NCI goes negative. No limit.

questions.question: IFRS 15 and ASC 606 revenue recognition standards are:

options.B: Substantially converged with minor differences

questions.explanation: IFRS 15 and ASC 606 are substantially converged, using the same 5-step model. Minor differences exist in areas like: licensing, collectibility threshold, non-cash consideration, and interim disclosure requirements.
questions.tip: IFRS 15/ASC 606: Converged standards, same 5 steps. Minor differences exist but approach is aligned.

questions.question: Under IFRS, biological assets (livestock, crops) are generally measured at:

options.B: Fair value less costs to sell
options.C: Lower of cost or net realizable value

questions.explanation: IAS 41 requires biological assets to be measured at fair value less costs to sell, with changes in value recognized in profit or loss. US GAAP doesn't have a specific biological assets standard—uses normal inventory/asset rules.
questions.tip: IFRS biological assets: FV less costs to sell. US GAAP: No specific standard—use inventory/PPE rules.

questions.question: An embedded derivative must be separated from its host contract when:

options.A: The host is a financial asset under ASC 320
options.B: The hybrid would not be measured at FV through earnings, and the embedded meets derivative criteria
options.D: The embedded is a put option

questions.explanation: Bifurcate if: (1) economic characteristics not clearly related to host, (2) hybrid isn't measured at FV-NI, (3) embedded would be a derivative if freestanding. For financial assets, bifurcation isn't allowed—use FV for entire instrument.
questions.tip: Embedded derivatives: Bifurcate if not related to host + hybrid not at FV-NI. Financial assets = no bifurcation.

questions.question: To qualify for hedge accounting, formal documentation must be prepared:

options.B: At hedge inception

questions.explanation: Formal hedge documentation must exist at hedge inception, specifying: hedging relationship, hedged item, hedging instrument, risk being hedged, and how effectiveness will be assessed. No retroactive designation.
questions.tip: Hedge documentation: Required at inception. No after-the-fact hedge accounting. Document risk, item, instrument, method.

questions.question: When measuring the fair value of a large holding of securities, a blockage discount:

options.B: Is prohibited for Level 1 measurements
options.D: Is only applied to restricted securities

questions.explanation: ASC 820 prohibits adjusting Level 1 prices for the size of the position (blockage factor). The quoted price times quantity is used. The unit of account may differ from the unit of valuation.
questions.tip: Blockage discount: Not allowed for Level 1. Use quoted price × quantity regardless of position size.

questions.question: Fair value of a non-financial asset considers its highest and best use, which must be:

options.A: The current use by the reporting entity
options.B: Physically possible, legally permissible, and financially feasible
options.C: The use that maximizes short-term cash flows
options.D: The original intended use when acquired

questions.explanation: Highest and best use considers what market participants would consider, constrained by what is: physically possible, legally permissible (zoning, etc.), and financially feasible. May differ from current use.
questions.tip: Highest and best use: Physical, legal, financial feasibility. Market participant view, not entity-specific.

questions.question: An operating segment is separately reportable if it meets any of the 10% tests. These tests compare the segment to:

options.B: Combined amounts for all operating segments

questions.explanation: 10% tests: (1) Revenue ≥10% of combined revenue, (2) Profit/loss ≥10% of greater of combined profits or losses, (3) Assets ≥10% of combined assets. Meet any one = reportable.
questions.tip: 10% tests: Revenue, profit/loss, assets compared to combined totals. Any one met = separately reportable.

questions.question: Operating segments are identified based on information regularly reviewed by the:

options.B: Board of directors

questions.explanation: Operating segments are based on how the chief operating decision maker (CODM) reviews internal reports to allocate resources and assess performance. The CODM is a function, not necessarily a specific title.
questions.tip: CODM defines segments: Internal reporting structure determines segment identification. Management approach.

questions.question: At interim periods, income tax expense is computed using:

options.B: The estimated annual effective tax rate applied to year-to-date income

questions.explanation: Interim tax expense = Estimated annual effective rate × Year-to-date ordinary income, minus prior interim tax expense. Discrete items (unusual, infrequent) are recognized entirely in the interim period they occur.
questions.tip: Interim tax: Use estimated annual rate on YTD income. Discrete items recognized when they occur.

questions.question: An inventory write-down at an interim date due to market decline is:

options.B: Recognized in the interim period, unless recovery is expected before year-end

questions.explanation: Interim inventory losses from market declines are recognized unless recovery is expected before year-end. If recovery occurs, restore the loss (but not above original cost). This is the integral view for interim periods.
questions.tip: Interim inventory loss: Recognize unless recovery expected before year-end. Can reverse if market recovers.

questions.question: Under ASU 2016-09, companies may account for forfeitures of stock compensation awards by:

options.A: Estimating forfeitures at grant date only
options.B: Either estimating expected forfeitures or recognizing actual forfeitures as they occur
options.D: Recognizing forfeitures only for terminated employees

questions.explanation: ASU 2016-09 provides a policy election: estimate forfeitures (traditional approach) OR recognize forfeitures as they occur (simpler, reversing expense when forfeiture happens). Election applies to all awards.
questions.tip: Forfeitures: Policy choice—estimate or recognize when occur. ASU 2016-09 simplified this.
